{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3717979,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-18T18:41:45.935Z","cooked":"

I swear I have run across multiple devices to get sensors onto CAN bus, OTHER than the CANDI from CTRE. But, darned if I can get CD search to cough them up.

Help out a grey haired mentor! I know there’s some sweet board that has multiple DIO and Analog IO on it… But I can’t remember who makes it!

We’ve dreamed up an outreach bot chassis (small enough to drop into a trunk). The idea with it is you can swap the top sheet to have an outreach mechanism or a prototype. I need to minimize the number of jumps between the base and the toppers. To do that I’ve got a second power distribution board on the topper, and a SB50 to connect the two. NOT competition legal, of course!

image796×364 46.5 KB

It would be super cool if we could put something on either the base or the sheets to tell the brain what’s installed on top and which code it wants. A pneumatics hub isn’t totally crazy, as it has two analogs, a digital input, high power output, and a raft of low power outputs. I could see having each topper with its own special CAN address. Just scan the bus and go “ah, topper #3 is installed!”.

I think most CAN boards I’ve seen here are personal/team projects instead of commercial products. The only one I can recall right now is REV’s data port breakout board. It doesn’t have many I/O ports, though, so it might not work for you application.

I swear there is another commercial CAN board besides the CANdi and CANifier from CTRE…

The question is what do you want to do with the data from the sensor once it’s on the CAN bus. If all you want to do is read it to the roboRIO and process it there, then you can use a COTS CAN adapter (like @truher posted), or any Talon SRX or SPARK MAX. But then you couls also just run the digital/analog signal wires directly to the roboRIO.

If the purpose of putting the sensor data on the CAN bus is for a CAN motor controller to read it as a remote sensor, your options are more limited. For CTRE devices (Krakens & Falcons), you need to use either a CANdi, a CANifier (no longer produced) or a Talon SRX data port. Not sure how it works for REV but I imagine the options are similar.

They pretty much force you into buying either their CAN-enabled sensors or using their proprietary CAN interface boards. Not that that’s not understandable, as it takes considerable time and effort to create the communication and control protocols for remote sensors and they need to recoup those costs somehow.

My main application is for our outreach robot/test mule.

It has everything on a small chassis. A swappable perforated plate bolts on top. A SB50 jumps to a second breaker panel under the top. Not competition legal, of course. I’d like to -just- jump CAN across and avoid a bunch of “oops” prone analog and digital jumps.

20250713_1750501920×1440 394 KB
